awd_titl_txt: Quantum Fluctuations and Broken Symmetries in Correlated Electron Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports theoretical research and education on a variety of problems that are interlinked by the common threads of quantum fluctuations and broken symmetries when electronic correlations are important. This project will address: high temperature superconductivity in cuprates, dissipative quantum phase transitions in general, and in particular, in low dimensional systems such as nanowires, and the role of disorder in quantum phase transitions applicable to many condensed matter systems, from cuprates to heavy fermions to organics. 

The recent discovery of quantum oscillations in cuprate superconductors has ushered in a new era of this twenty-year old unsolved major problem in physics. A theoretical understanding of this phenomenon may result in a major breakthrough. The PI's approach is to model the various broken symmetry states, with particular attention paid to coexisting states of competing order parameters in the vortex liquid state. The PI will employ exact transfer matrix technique and Landauer-Pichard formula to compute Shubnikov-de Haas oscillations. Dissipative quantum phase transitions are addressed because of their potential importance in shedding light on the foundations of quantum mechanics, as well as their key role in a novel class of quantum criticality, with many applications. Numerical simulations as well as scaling theories will be used. A specific application of the theory is the ongoing experiments in quantum phase slips in nanowires. In the same broad framework, the PI will also investigate the role of disorder in phase transitions, in particular quantum phase transitions. Many complex materials of great importance in understanding correlated electron systems are inevitably rife with disorder. Both the tools of rigorous mathematical statistical mechanics as well as numerical simulations in well-defined quantum models will be addressed. There are many cases where some unorthodox thinking may be required; the notion of quantum mechanical entanglement entropy, the von Neumann entropy, is one of them. 

This award also supports training graduate students in theoretical condensed matter physics. Research activities will enhance teaching in undergraduate classes, where there are now many more minorities and women students. It is at this undergraduate level that the PI will encourage students to pursue careers in science.

NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports theoretical research and education on quantum phase transitions. These are an intensely studied phenomenon that has become cutting edge research in condensed matter physics. Ordinary phase transitions, like the transition of water to ice, take place at non-zero temperature and are driven by thermal fluctuations. Quantum phase transitions can take place at the absolute zero of temperature driven by the quantum fluctuations of Heisenberg's uncertainty principle. The PI aims to explore novel materials that have been discovered in recent years in this new light and to explain their observable, and so far puzzling, properties. 

This research may lead to further progress in predicting useful materials, such as materials that might exhibit superconductivity at room temperatures. Superconductivity is a quantum mechanical state of matter that so far occurs at low temperatures, at most about twice the frigid temperature where the element nitrogen, a gaseous component of our atmosphere, boils. Superconductors can carry electricity without loss. At the same time we would be learning fundamental aspects of quantum properties of matter. This research may lead to further understanding of novel materials that may form the foundations of future technologies.

This award also supports training graduate students in theoretical condensed matter physics. Research activities will enhance teaching in undergraduate classes, where there are now many more minorities and women students. It is at this undergraduate level that the PI will encourage students to pursue careers in science.

Strongly correlated systems often result in unexpectedly rich emergent phenomena. In condensed matter physics the underlying microscopic building blocks are fully known in terms of electrons and ions, but the emergent collective states of matter, such as superconductivity, are difficult to predict (broken symmetries).  The intention of my project was to study aspects of quantum condensed matter systems: high temperature superconductivity in cuprates and, in general, strongly correlated electron systems. These are major unsolved problems in physics. The tools employed involved both analytical and numerical methods that are at the cutting edge of research.

One of the  projects involved addressing the startling phenomenon discovered recently, known as quantum oscillations, in ultra high magnetic field laboratories. These experiments shed light into the state of matter from which high temperature superconductors arise. Quantum oscillations is an inherently quantum mechanical interference phenomenon that results in wave-like oscillations as a function of the applied magnetic field of many physical properties, such as magnetization, conductivity, etc. They are collectively known as quantum oscillations. It is hoped that this understanding will be important in designing even higher temperature superconductors, perhaps even room temperature superconductors in which dissipationless electric currents can flow, which would be a major technological adavnce. These experiments  have also challenged the imagination of the theorists as to how one should think in general about quantum states of matter accessible at low temperatures, because they raise questions about the fundamental quantum states of matter.

The next topic consisted of emergent gauge theories (similar to gauge theories that describe electromagnetism) in condensed matter systems that form a fascinating subject of research with a wide set of applications in  novel materials with remarkable experimental implications. In particular, it challenges the conventional paradigm of how superconductivity arises in the first place.

Another direction of research was the fascinating effect of disorder (inevitably present in all real materials)  in  especially quantum systems. In this context, it was discussed how ubiquitous discontinuous change of a phase of matter can become continuous in the presence of disorder. This surprising phenomenon happens for both classical or quantum statistical mechanical systems. The topic engenders an extremely complex challenge and can influence the quantum mechanical behavior of a condensed matter system. 

One of the broader impacts of this work involved training graduate students  and postdocs to assume leadership roles in the society at large. This required not only mentoring students at the home institution, but also encouraging them to attend professional meetings, where they can present the results of their research activities and exchange ideas with others in the field. Funding from the National Science Foundation (NSF) was crucial in this respect. During the past grant period three undergraduate women were mentored, although only one of them was partially funded by NSF; they have gone on to major graduate schools: University of Oxford, University of Pennsylvania, and Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Recruiting women and minorities is a challenging task in our field. In addition, a woman postdoc who switched from string theory to condensed matter theory was also supervised.  She helped me in one of my projects.
